subject: RE: Ant/JUnit (RE: [junit] How to record test results in XML format)
msgSnippet: Actually, optional.jar and junit.jar have to be loaded by the same classloader, so put both in Ant s lib directory, so Ant s startup classloader finds them
messageBody:
Actually, optional.jar and junit.jar have to be loaded by the same
classloader, so put both in Ant's lib directory, so Ant's startup classloader finds them both.

The junit task will not be available if Ant loads optional.jar and
can't find junit.jar via the same classloader.

Take a look at
http://jakarta.apache.org/ant/faq.html#delegating-classloader
or ask the ant-user mailing list.

Andy.

--
Andrew Beacock
Principal Software Engineer
Nokia
NMP/MSW/SSP/MMS

> -----Original Message-----
> From: ext J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbr@...]
> Sent: Thursday, July 11, 2002 8:22 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: OT: Ant/JUnit (RE: [junit] How to record test results in XML
> format)
>
>
> Could be. I remember just putting in the CLASSPATH *anywhere* and
> having it work; but then, I might have been setting the Ant CLASSPATH
> explicitly when I ran it. An ugly workaround, but it was good
> enough at
> the time. :)
>
> *********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********
>
> On 2002-07-11 at 08:08 Ken Gentle wrote:
>
> >IIRC, 'optional.jar' has to be placed in ${ANT_HOME}/lib - I think
> this
> >has
> >to do with ant's custom classloading and where it looks for tasks.
> >
> >Placing it in the Classpath prior to invoking Ant may not have the
> desired
> >result.
> >
> >Or I could be totally wrong (again!)
> >
> > Ken
> >
> >At 01:15 PM 7/11/02 +0200, you wrote:
> >
> >
> >> > -----Original Message-----
> >> > From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jacaetevha@...]
> >> >
> >> >
> >> > O.K. anyone else feel free to jump in... (thanks J.B.)
> >> >
> >> > try putting optional.jar on your CLASSPATH as well...
> >> >
> >> > It generally isn't this hard.
> >> >
> >> > BTW: I thought JBungler had an Ant integration module.
> >>
> >>Maybe the integrated JBuilder's JUnit and/or Ant are being used
> instead of
> >>the the version You installed separately. Adding the optional.jar to
> the
> >>wrong lib directory wouldn't solve anything.
> >>Search your harddisk(s) for ant.jar, I suspect you will find more
> than
> >>one...
> >>
> >> >
> >> > =jason
> >> >
